automaton module¶

Contains the classes to represent a non-deterministic finite automaton.

class automaton.Automaton(initial_state, states)[source]¶

Represents a non-deterministic finite automaton.

An automaton has the following attributes:
  • initial_state: the name of the initial state
  • states: a dict representing its states that maps a name into the corresponding state
find_reachable_states(initial_state)[source]¶

Performs a depth-first search, starting from its initial state.

The states that are involved in this search are marked as visited.

Parameters:initial_state (str) – the name of its initial state
get_initial_state()[source]¶

Gets the initial state’s name of this automaton.

Returns:the name of its initial state
Return type:str
get_loops()[source]¶

Gets all the simple cycles of this automaton.

The cycles are returned as a list of tuples, sorted by their length. Each tuple represents a cycle and it is composed by the sequence of the names of the states taking part to that cycle.

Returns:all the simple cycles of this automaton
Return type:list(tuple(str))
get_states()[source]¶

Gets the name-state map of this automaton.

Returns:its name-state map
Return type:dict(str: State)
get_transitions(unobservable=False)[source]¶

Gets the transitions of this automaton.

The transitions are returned as a list of tuples in which the first element is the source name and the second one is the destination name. If unobservable is True it returns only the unobservable transitions of this automaton, otherwise it returns all its transitions.

Parameters:unobservable (bool) – a flag indicating whether to include only unobservable transitions
Returns:the transitions of this automaton according to unobservable flag
Return type:list(tuple(str, str))
get_unobservable_transitions()[source]¶

Gets the unobservable transitions of this automaton.

Returns:the unobservable transitions of this automaton
Return type:list(Transition)
has_ambiguous_events()[source]¶

Checks if this automaton has at least an ambiguous event.

In our definition, an event is ambiguous if it is associated both to a fault transition and to an observable one.

Returns:whether this automaton has at least an ambiguous event
Return type:bool
has_fault_loops()[source]¶

Checks if this automaton has at least a cycle composed only of fault transitions.

Returns:whether this automaton has at least a cycle composed only of fault transitions or not
Return type:bool
is_language_alive()[source]¶

Checks if the language generated by this automaton on its events alphabet is alive.

The language is alive if:
  • every state has at least one outgoing transition
  • every cyclic path starting from the initial state contains at least an observable transition
Returns:whether the language generated by this automaton on its events alphabet is alive or not
Return type:bool
is_non_deterministic()[source]¶

Checks if this automaton is non-deterministic.

An automaton is non-deterministic if there is at least a couple of outgoing transitions from the same state and sharing the same event.

Returns:whether this automaton is non-deterministic or not
Return type:bool
remove_unreachable_states()[source]¶

Removes the states that are unreachable from the initial state.

To perform this task, a depth-first search is used.

set_states(states)[source]¶

Sets the name-state map.

Parameters:states (dict(str: State)) – the name-state map to be set
set_transition_event(src_name, dst_name, event)[source]¶

Sets an event to a transition.

This function is invoked during the first phase of the random generation of an automaton. In this phase there is only one outgoing transition from one state to a neighbour, so a transition can be identified by its source state’s name and its destination state’s name. An event is not added when the transition has an event already associated.

Parameters:
  • src_name (str) – the source state’s name of the transition
  • dst_name (str) – the destination state’s name of the transition
  • event (Event) – the event to be set
Returns:

whether the event has been set or not
Return type:

bool
class automaton.Event(name=None)[source]¶

Represents a (composed) event associated to a transition.

An event has the following attributes:
  • multiset: a Counter representing the multiset of its components
add(event)[source]¶

Adds the components of an event to this event.

Parameters:event (Event) – the event to be added
get_level()[source]¶

Gets the level of this event.

The level of a composed event is its components multiset’s cardinality.

Returns:the level of this event
Return type:int
get_name()[source]¶

Gets the name of this event.

If its level is greater than 1, the name is obtained concatenating the names of its components using ‘//’ as separator.

Returns:the name of this event
Return type:str
is_composed_by_all_identical_instances()[source]¶

Checks if this event is composed by all identical instances of events.

Returns:whether this event is composed by all identical instances of events or not
Return type:bool
class automaton.State(name)[source]¶

Represents a state of the automaton.

A state has the following attributes:
  • name: a string representing its name
  • neighbours: a dict representing its neighbours that maps a state into a list of transitions
  • visited: a boolean flag used during depth-first search
add_transition(neighbour, transition)[source]¶

Adds an outgoing transition from this state towards a neighbour.

A transition is not added when:
  • it’s a self loop unobservable transition
  • it creates a loop of unobservable transitions between this state and its neighbour
  • it’s already present (see beelow)
Parameters:
  • neighbour (State) – the neighbour state
  • transition (Transition) – the transition to be added
Returns:

whether the transition has been added or not
Return type:

bool
equals(state)[source]¶

Checks if this state is equal to another.

Two states are equal if they have the same name.

Parameters:state (State) – the state with which the comparison is performed
Returns:whether this state is equal to another or not
Return type:bool
get_current_level_transitions(level, fault=True)[source]¶

Gets the transitions whose (composed) event is of a certain level.

If fault is False it returns only the non fault outgoing transitions from this state towards its neighbours, otherwise it returns all the outgoing transitions from this state towards its neighbour (according to level).

Parameters:
  • level (int) – the level through which filter which transitions to get
  • fault (bool) – a flag indicating whether to include fault transitions or not
Returns:

the neighbour-transitions map according to level and fault flag
Return type:

dict(State: list(Transition))
get_name()[source]¶

Gets the name of this state.

Returns:the name of this state
Return type:str
get_neighbour(name)[source]¶

Gets the neighbour of this state, according to its name.

Parameters:name (str) – the neighbour’s name
Returns:the neighbour state if exists, otherwise None
Return type:State or None
get_neighbours(fault=True)[source]¶

Gets the neighbour-transitions map of this state.

If fault is False it returns only the non fault outgoing transitions from this state towards its neighbours, otherwise it returns all the outgoing transitions from this state to its neighbours.

Parameters:fault (bool) – a flag indicating whether to include fault transitions or not
Returns:the neighbour-transitions map of this state according to fault flag
Return type:dict(State: list(Transition))
has_observable_transitions(neighbour)[source]¶

Checks if this state has at least an observable transition towards a neighbour.

Parameters:neighbour (State) – the neighbour state
Returns:whether this state has at least an observable transition towards a neighbour
Return type:bool
has_unobservable_transitions(neighbour)[source]¶

Checks if this state has at least an unobservable transition towards a neighbour.

Parameters:neighbour (State) – the neighbour state
Returns:whether this state has at least an unobservable transition towards a neighbour
Return type:bool
is_visited()[source]¶

Checks if this state has been already visited.

Returns:whether this state has been visited or not
Return type:bool
set_transitions(neighbour, transitions)[source]¶

Sets a list of outgoing transitions from this state towards a neighbour.

Parameters:
  • neighbour (State) – the neighbour state
  • transitions (list(Transition)) – the list of transitions to be set
set_visited(visited=True)[source]¶

Sets the boolean flag of this state.

Parameters:visited (bool) – the new flag
transition_already_present(neighbour, _transition)[source]¶

Checks if an outgoing transition from this state towards a neighbour is already present.

Between two states cannot exist a couple of transitions sharing the same event, unless one is fault and the other not.

Parameters:
  • neighbour (State) – the neighbour state
  • _transition (Transition) – the transition to check
Returns:

whether the transition is already present or not
Return type:

bool
class automaton.Transition(event=None, fault=False, ambiguous=False)[source]¶

Represents a transition of the automaton.

A transition has the following attributes:
  • event: the event associated to the transition
  • fault: a boolean flag marking it as fault
  • ambiguous: a boolean flag marking it as ambiguous
get_event()[source]¶

Gets the event associated to this transition.

Returns:the event associated to the transition
Return type:Event
get_event_level()[source]¶

Gets the level of the event associated to this transition.

If no event is associated to this transition it returns 0.

Returns:the level of the event associated to this transition
Return type:int
get_event_name()[source]¶

Gets the name of the event associated to this transition.

If no event is associated to this transition it returns None.

Returns:the name of the event associated to this transition if exists, otherwise None
Return type:str or None
is_ambiguous()[source]¶

Checks if this transition is ambiguous.

Returns:whether this transition is ambiguous or not
Return type:bool
is_fault()[source]¶

Checks if this transition is fault.

Returns:whether this transition is fault or not
Return type:bool
is_observable()[source]¶

Checks if this transition is observable.

A transition is observable if there is a not null event associated to it

Returns:whether the transition is observable or not
Return type:bool
set_event(event)[source]¶

Associates an event to this transition.

Parameters:event (Event) – the event to be associated to this transition
set_fault()[source]¶

Marks this transition as fault.
